Political [underlined]; agricultural [underlined]; chiefs in fishing, yes, for migrations, yes
seasonal changes of residence between permanent communities
[not marked with + nor -] ?; a row of dwellings (Sproat 1868: 39); houses placed regularly along streets (Bancroft 1875: 183)
chief mode of travel was canoe
chief mode of travel was canoe
chief mode of travel was canoe
secret fraternity "in a house covered round in the inside with mats"
extensively [underlined]; carved [underlined]; steel ax, knife, adz from Ocean trade w/ whites created "a great efflorescence" of wood carving (Service 1958: 210)
functional differentiation [underlined]; separation of nuclear family units (Sproat 1868: 42); de emphasized by Drucker (1951: 72)
full-time [underlined]; discussion of specialists in Drucker (1951: 273)
?; improved [underlined]; no "improvement" of land; Inherited jurisdiction over economic resources – fishing, hunting, gathering grounds – but kinsmen may[?] use the resource
personal effects given away before death or buried with corpse except best canoes, house plank, tools, weapons
gradual "inheriting" of ceremonial privileges by means of potlatches
gradual "inheriting" of ceremonial privileges by means of potlatches
exchange [underlined]; most men had a craft, were "specialists" of some sort
chief may send commoner out to hunt if he needs game for a feast

for hair seals killed, wealth not mentioned specifically
of slaves (Drucker 1951: 272); of articles made especially by other tribes (Sproat 1868: 19)

not distinguished terminologically in Nootka. Simpler polities; lineage "local group" – family of chiefs who owned territorial rights, houses, privileges. Not usually autonomous – descent from common ancestor according to tradition but hard to trace; tribe – formally united group of lineages at a single winter site – great houses – important ceremonies; confederacy – union of tribes at summer site – war + ceremonies

Service (1958: 215): not strata  but series of individual status positions in ranked order; Drucker (1951: 244): chiefs, commoners, slaves; among chiefs some are called "high chiefs" others "half chiefs" or "small chiefs" (Sproat 1868: 115)
paint, robe color (Bancroft 1875: 180-182); wool only for chiefs (Drucker 1951: 101) – on ordinary occasions no class differences in dress (Sproat 1868: 25)
?; "tributes" by lower status kinsmen who use resources "owned" by higher status kinsman but the latter has no power to enforce "tribute." He will redistribute such wealth
?; slave assigned as companion to chief’s child
usually [underlined]; "Polygyny is sometimes practiced by important chiefs" (Service 1958: 221); see Drucker (1951: 301): "all his wives" – "several";  "seldom more than one" (Sproat 1868: 100)

?; possessions of deceased are given away or destroyed (Service 1958: 221); chiefs buried w/ skins, blankets and large amounts of other property – or these are burned w/ him or hung about his box (Bancroft 1875: 205)
year-round < - no; "tribe based" on winter residence, confederacy based on common summer residence – unit for war
policy [underlined]; a [underlined] formally recognized agent - chiefs
speaker, war chief, clown (Drucker 1951: 269); council of chiefs (Boas 1890: 585)
no subdivisions of territory according to various septs within the tribe; see Drucker (1951: 220)
regular?; elders called together by head chief – people must consent to decisions
at least 8 or 10 [underlined]; "seldom more than one" (Sproat 1868: 100)
Special [underlined]; potlatch by which father gives heir his place – legally if not actually (Drucker 1951: 266-267); also potlatch given by heir after death of chief (Boas 1890: 588)
ceremonial leader – ritual bathing "to feed his people" – ?
?; chief – chiefs??; luxury [underlined]; blankets, skins and large amts. of other goods; valuables put with (optional) memorial
for taboos broken in Shaman’s Dance
counsel of kinsmen or public reprimands
law [underlined] - no "law"; chief acted badly was spoken against, finally left "Informants do not know what would have happened to a man of lesser rank who behaved like moqwina", none ever did?

regularly [underlined]; War chief appointed by people, retains office until displaced (Sproat 1868); command of military force in hands of chief or war chief who had instigated the war; sometimes chief delegated field command to war chiefs (Drucker 1951: 336)
?; "some sources" say all able-bodied men are subject to serve when called by commander"
"the Ahts cannot understand why the great king-George tribe should leave all their fighting to a few men"
natives [underlined] -> who go to "visit" relatives; at early stages of warfare
simple raiding, no protracted battles (Service 1958: 225); no (Bancroft 1875: 189); + "Bold frontal attacks were planned but usually failed" (Drucker 1951: 337)
war refuge resorted to only in time of danger or temporary stockades were built
sieges spoken of but must have been rare – attackers starving before besieged (Drucker 1951: 338)
"Success in war is a broad stepping-stone in an ambitious career"; property rights gained by warfare less "noble"
sometimes taken captive to be killed at leisure
no real worship, therefore no gods (Service 1958: 222); 4 "Great Chiefs" rule segments of universe prayed to (Drucker 1963: 140); Worship of moon and sun prayer (Sproat 1868: 206)

Sproat (1868: 156) describes a "sacrifice of a slave woman, which is apparently part of the Shaman’s dance. However, Drucker does not mention sacrifice in his detailed description of the Dance. Besides, the Shaman dance is more a secular than a religious ceremony, [unreadable] Service. Besides, Dr. Stan Freed says "no" for all N. W. coast; + sacrifice and cannibalism (Bancroft 1875: 203); sometimes killing of slaves when chief dies (Sproat 1868)
?; shrines exist; at least one shrine was located in a remote place
receptacles only of bladder, wood, basketry
may have been used by some earlier
Hair – dogs hair mixed with cedar bark (Bancroft 1875: 182); wool [underlined]; goat wool (Drucker 1951: 94)
loom-woven [underlined]; textiles <- all kinds of weaves, no loom mentioned

predominant [underlined]; in 1874 metal has long since replaced shell, slate, flint and bone for lances and arrowheads for fighting but some hunting and fishing utensils are still of traditional materials (Bancroft 1875: 188)
Boas (1891: 590) says coppers are not used in Nootka potlatch
none in prehistoric times (Sproat 1868: 83); idea came from Meares around 1788
sailors, pilots, or navigators [underlined]; older men, paid if not close relative – steersman, in charge
no knowledge of anatomy nor clear idea of circulation of blood
